results.title: All quiet on the Western Front
results.creator_credit: Delbert Mann, Norman Rosemont and Marble Arch Productions
results.brief_description: Made for television, this adaptation of Erich Maria Remarque’s passionate anti-war novel is a remake of the 1930’s film classic about young German soldiers in the Great war of 1914-18, and of the veteran who teaches them to grow up fast in the trenches. Stars Richard Thomas, Ernest Borgnine, Patricia Neal, Ian Holm and Donald Pleasence.

results.title: Making of a legend: Gone with the wind
results.creator_credit: David Hinton, L. Jeffrey Selznick, Selznick Properties and Turner Entertainment
results.brief_description: A feature length documentary which takes a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the 1939 feature film “Gone With the Wind”. Utilises some rare film footage including several screen tests for the part of Scarlett O’Hara, and home movies featuring Vivien Leigh. A fascinating inside view of one of the great accomplishments in motion picture history. Narrated by Christopher Plummer.

results.title: Glass menagerie
results.creator_credit: Paul Newman, Burtt Harris and Columbia
results.brief_description: A shy girl seeks escape from reality of life in the St. Louis of the Great Depression and from her mother’s fantasies of constantly reliving the glory of her youth. The fragile balance of the family is changed when her brother arranges for a “gentleman caller” to pay a visit. Based on the play by Tennesse Williams. Stars Joanne Woodward, John Malkovich and Karen Allen.

results.title: Cornflakes for tea
results.creator_credit: John Colquhoun, Tom Broadbridge and Andromeda Productions
results.brief_description: Dramatization of how a family living in high-rise inner city flats manage to cope with caring for each other when first their mother and then their father abandon them. Provides many points which could act as stimulus for discussion including perspectives on family relationships, contrasts on single parent and conventional nuclear families, welfare workers and their role, supportive community members, and the warm relationship of the central characters.

results.title: The Princess diaries
results.creator_credit: Garry Marshall, Mario Iscovich and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Mia Thermopolis is a bright but terribly shy and gawky teenager whose goal in life is to survive each school day with a minimum of attention and embarrassment. Unfortunately, her wish to be invisible is thwarted when her strict grandmother arrives and delivers the shocking news that she’s a real-life princess - heir to the throne of Genovia. Based on the novel by Meg Cabot. Cast includes Anne Hathaway, Heather Matarazzo, Hector Elizondo, Julie Andrews, Mandy Moore, Caroline Goodall.

results.title: Dimboola [DVD]
results.creator_credit: John Duigan, John Weiley and Pram Factory Pictures
results.brief_description: Jack Hibberd’s famous stage comedy is brought to the screen by director John Duigan (“The Year My Voice Broke”). The wedding of Morrie (played by Bruce Spence) to Maureen (Natalie Bate) in the small country town of Dimboola is the setting for this story of “typical Aussie ratbags and oddballs doing typically dim-witted Aussie things usually whilst chucking back a tinnie and trying to crack on to a sheila” (according to critic Bernard Hemingway). A visiting English journalist (played by Max Gillies) observes and comments on the action. Filmed on location at Dimboola in western Victoria, and including many of the cast from the Australian Performing Group’s highly successful theatrical production, “Dimboola” is a colourful and uniquely Australian romp. Cast also includes Bill Garner, Evelyn Krape, Max Cullen, Max Fairchild, and Chad Morgan. This DVD edition also includes a filmed version of the original play as performed at the Pram Factory in 1973 and a 1994 documentary on the Australian Performing Group with some wonderful archival footage.

results.title: Hoodwink [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Claude Whatham, Errol Sullivan, Pom Oliver, CB Films (France) and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: John Hargreaves stars as Martin Stang, a character based on a real-life bank robber and conman, in this Australian “crime caper” film. Martin attempts to ease the burden of his time in a New South Wales jail by pretending to be blind. While he succeeds in fooling the authorities into giving him special treatment, unexpected complications arise when Martin meets Sarah, (Judy Davis) the wife of a local lay preacher, and becomes emotionally involved. The stellar Australian cast also includes Wendy Hughes, Colin Friels, Max Cullen, Michael Caton and Geoffrey Rush in his first film role. Judy Davis won the 1981 AFI Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role for her performance.
